channel.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
channel.description:
[s]Alright so I have downloaded the [url=http://releases.ubuntu.com/lucid/ubuntu-10.04.1-desktop-i386.iso.torrent]ubuntu-10.04.1-desktop-i386.iso[/url] torrent. I ran the Universal USB installer and used my E:\ drive for Ubuntu. However when I try booting it from the USB (I already edited my Boot Order to removable disks as the first choice), Windows XP starts up. :mad:
Am I doing anything wrong? Please help, thanks. :)[/s]
The problem has been fixed. My USB was under the Hard Drive category (there were the hard disk and USB options) on the boot menu. All I had to do was move it up.

item.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Elijah:

Tell us the model/brand motherboard. Of all the computers I’ve worked on, it’s always been boot from USB Device, not Removable drive.

The model is 26831A1. I’ve searched for its compatibility with USB booting and I have no results.

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:10, topic:366929”]Mopar, sometimes it boots to the HDD in the case that the USB is not bootable.

My feel is that one of these is your problem:
a) Your USB isn’t bootable. Try on another computer. Try another USB installer, creating a bootable USB is tricky.
b) Your mobo indeed does not support USB booting (removable devices may refer to floppies).
c) You’re not on a i386 processor. Just to verify, what are your full PC specs?[/quote]
I have a text file of my PC specs after running CPU-Z, attached. I’m on an i386 processor btw.

Read full topic
item.source: Ubuntu is not booting from USB

item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Mopar, sometimes it boots to the HDD in the case that the USB is not bootable.

My feel is that one of these is your problem:
a) Your USB isn’t bootable. Try on another computer. Try another USB installer, creating a bootable USB is tricky.
b) Your mobo indeed does not support USB booting (removable devices may refer to floppies).
c) You’re not on a i386 processor. Just to verify, what are your full PC specs?

item.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:7, topic:366929”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=463124.msg3388143#msg3388143 date=1288661460]

Don’t just rely on ‘auto boot order’, press whatever button you need to go to the boot selection screen, and manually select your USB drive. See how that works and post back here.

I’ve done that as well, but it still starts Windows up.
[/quote]

I don’t think you did do it. Did it actually allow you to select your USB drive? If so, there is no way it should have booted to windows.[/quote]
I pressed F12 and it brought me to the screen to select from which device I want to boot from. I chose removable devices but it still started Windows up.

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:6, topic:366929”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=463124.msg3388143#msg3388143 date=1288661460]

Don’t just rely on ‘auto boot order’, press whatever button you need to go to the boot selection screen, and manually select your USB drive. See how that works and post back here.

I’ve done that as well, but it still starts Windows up.
[/quote]
There is a program called EasyBCD, and has the option to install, what it calls, a BIOS extender, when in reality its just another bootloader. As long as your USB is plugged in while your computer is booting up, load the “extender” and select the device. That’s what I had to do a while back, before I bought a CD-RW drive off of ebay.[/quote]
I’ll try that later.

Read full topic
item.source: Ubuntu is not booting from USB

item.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:5, topic:366929”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=463124.msg3387645#msg3387645 date=1288622817]
Don’t just rely on ‘auto boot order’, press whatever button you need to go to the boot selection screen, and manually select your USB drive. See how that works and post back here.
[/quote]
I’ve done that as well, but it still starts Windows up.[/quote]

I don’t think you did do it. Did it actually allow you to select your USB drive? If so, there is no way it should have booted to windows.

Read full topic
item.source: Ubuntu is not booting from USB

item.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:5, topic:366929”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=463124.msg3387645#msg3387645 date=1288622817]
Don’t just rely on ‘auto boot order’, press whatever button you need to go to the boot selection screen, and manually select your USB drive. See how that works and post back here.
[/quote]
I’ve done that as well, but it still starts Windows up.[/quote]
There is a program called EasyBCD, and has the option to install, what it calls, a BIOS extender, when in reality its just another bootloader. As long as your USB is plugged in while your computer is booting up, load the “extender” and select the device. That’s what I had to do a while back, before I bought a CD-RW drive off of ebay.

Read full topic
item.source: Ubuntu is not booting from USB

item.title: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Thug-life:

Some motherboards don’t support booting from USB afaik, I’m not sure what happens when they don’t support it, so I couldn’t say if that is the problem, but it is worth looking up the details of your motherboard.

I found my motherboard model. I’ve searched whether it supports booting from USB, but no results.

Moparisthebest:

Don’t just rely on ‘auto boot order’, press whatever button you need to go to the boot selection screen, and manually select your USB drive. See how that works and post back here.

I’ve done that as well, but it still starts Windows up.

Mopman:

If your motherboard recognizes USB devices as hard drives rather than their own category of device, you may have to change the boot hard drive in the BIOS to the USB one before you can select it from the menu, since many motherboards only allow one hard drive to be the bootable one.

I did so.

Does the file system of my USB affect booting?

Read full topic
item.source: Ubuntu is not booting from USB
